story: Schoolgirl, , told to stop eating sugary snacks by doctor actually had cancerLyra Cassell, , from Allerton, Liverpool, was initially told she should reduce the amount of sugar she was eating after finding two lumps, but after further tests scans, it was revealed she had an aggressive form of cancerLyra Cassell, , from Allerton was initially told to reduce the amount of sugar she is eating after finding two lumps Image: Family handoutByCharlotte HadfieldShiler Mahmoudi:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA schoolgirl was told to stop eating sugar snacks and drinks by a doctor when in actual fact, she had cancer. Lyra Cassell, , from Allerton, Liverpool, found a lump in her groin at the end of August and asked to see a doctor. Her mum, Hayley, says they were told the lump was a hernia, and that they could not get a hospital appointment for months due to an NHS backlog that has been caused by the pandemic.Hayley told the Liverpool Echo : She had a hernia as a baby so we thought it was nothing to worry about. Then we went for a walk in Garston Park and she went aposIaposve got this lump on my neck.apos It was on the side of her neck and it was quite big. I thought aposthataposs not right Lyraapos and I phoned the doctors again. Following her second appointment with a nurse, Lyra was referred for an appointment the hospital and a few days later she had her bloods taken by her GP. Hayley said: [The doctor] phoned me on the Tuesday morning to tell me she was anaemic and to stop giving her sweets and fizzy drinks. They said sheaposs not diabetic but her blood sugar levels are slightly high. However, two weeks later, Lyra went for an ultrasound appointment followed by a biopsy and further blood tests, and on September  received the devastating news that she had acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. She started receiving chemotherapy the next day. Mum Hayley said: Everything was going well for her. The fit and healthy Belvedere Academy student had recently smashed her GCSEs and was running five times a week for the Liverpool Harriers And Athletic Club. Hayley, , said: [Lyra] works in Ginoaposs restaurant in town part-time on the reception and she also taught dance in Liverpool College to four- year olds, so she was really busy and she was loving it. She was saying she was tired but we just put it down to working and going out with her friends. Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia is a type of cancer that affects white blood cells. It progresses quickly and aggressively and requires immediate treatment.  Hayley said: Lyraaposs first question was aposwill I lose my hair apos They explained to us that it will be a very dficult process of at least two years. It feels like itaposs someone  this has happened to - this doesnapost happen to us. Itaposs just horrendous. Two weeks ago I had a normal, and what we thought was a healthy teenager, ready to smash her A-levels and go out clubbing and do all the things we did as a   year old, and now everything is a train wreck. Lyra is currently undergoing treatment and has recently been diagnosed with steroid-induced diabetes. If Lyra hadnapost found the lump on her neck when she did, Hayley fears how long it would have been before she found out she had cancer. With this in mind, Hayley is keen to raise awareness and encourage others to get checked out at the first sign of symptoms.In a bid to help the family during this time, Lyraaposs running coach and family friend Jayne Teare has set up a Go Fund Me page.In a message on the page Jayne said: Lyra’s unique love of le and people shines through with most people she meets. She is warm, funny, goofy, caring, determined and very kind. She and her family are terried by what this new future holds and the upset it will have on Lyra and her loved ones. The journey will be long and dficult but we have to focus on the light at the end of the tunnel. Currently, le for Lyra is tough as she undergoes extensive chemotherapy and deals with the complications that this can cause. Any support or help you can offer would be greatly appreciated. story: Stepmum battered boy leaving him leless in hallway and then organised her birthdayDad Thomas Hughes, , and step-mum Emma Tustin, , are accused of murdering Arthur Labinjo-Hughes, from Solihull, West Midlands, with the trial heard at Coventry Crown CourtArthur Labinjo-Hughes, six, was found unresponsive at a home in Solihull, on June  last year Image: BPM MediaByCarl JacksonMatthew CooperCricket Trends Writer:,  Oct A step-mum accused of murder texted someone about party balloons around the time she allegedly delivered a fatal blow to a six-year-old. Dad Thomas Hughes, , and step-mum Emma Tustin, , are accused of mistreating Arthur Labinjo-Hughes before he suffered an un-survivable brain injury at his home in Cranmore Road, Solihull, West Midlands, on June  .The young boy died in hospital in the early hours of the following day, Birmingham Mail reported. Hughes and Tustin both deny murder. Yesterday in court on the sixth day of the trial jurors were played CCTV footage taken in the living room of the family home on June , when Arthur allegedly endured the fatal injury.  They were also shown texts between the Hughes and Tustin from that day, including a photo sent from the woman in which Arthur appears to be crying. From the home Tustin texted Hughes, who was out at the shops, multiple times, writing that the boy was grabbing walls and door and throwing himself down just before pm. They discussed whether a mark on his face was bruising before Tustin sent Hughes an audio clip of Arthur crying followed by a text saying: Still at it. The prosecution showed a clip of the woman leaving the living room for about a minute, during which time they contend she dealt Arthur the fatal blow. Jonas Hankin QC told the court that around this time Tustin texted the aposballoon ladyapos about her birthday decorations for an upcoming party. At .pm Tustin messaged Hughes: Just copped me in the stomach he has thrown himself all over the floor wonapost get up for s*** Iaposve shut the door on him.  A minute later she took a picture on her phone showing Arthur lying down in the hallway. The court was played living room footage showing Tustin walking into the kitchen before ing while looking at her phone and then walking into the hallway. She s carrying Arthur into the living room, Mr Hankin told the court. His body is limp. She carries Arthur into the kitchen then into the living room and places him on the floor. Arthur appears to be unconscious. His eyes are closed, body is limp. He falls to the left onto the floor. It appears his body is limp. Tustin gets up and goes into the kitchen. The next footage from .pm shows Tustin partially pick Arthur up from the floor and drag him into the hallway. She then reappears and places Arthur on the sofa before walking into the kitchen. Giving evidence in court earlier on Thursday, Tustinaposs hairdresser, Catherine Milhench, said she wished she had called police after seeing Arthur on June  and . Ms Milhench, who works from home and first cut Tustinaposs hair in the summer of , said she met Arthur later that year and he seemed absolutely fine, healthy, a normal boy.  Describing a hair appointment at her home in February , Ms Milhench said of Arthur: He was still, I would say, healthy-looking but not happy. He was made to sit downwith his hands on his knees and not move. Ms Milhench told the court: I just thought heaposs obviously been naughty at home. When you go to other peopleaposs you donapost want your child to misbehave. Answering questions from Mr Hankin, Ms Milhench said at another six-hour hair appointment on June  , Arthur was told by Tustin to stand by and face the front door. Mr Hankin asked Ms Milhench: Throughout the time that she was there in your home, how did she sheinteract with Arthur  The witness answered: Telling him to stand, not to lean on the door, to face the door... not to move. Tustin then went to the bathroom to have her hair washed, Ms Milhench said, adding of Arthur: He was made to come upstairs and face another door upstairs. She said he couldnapost be trusted. Asked for her view of Arthuraposs state during the visit, Ms Milhench said: Deteriorated. You could see his collar bones. He was wearing a pyjama onesie and you could just see his collar bones sticking out.  I didnapost remember that from last time. He had lost weight. Using the phrase like skeletal to describe what Arthuraposs condition made her think of, Ms Milhench said the boy appeared to be drained and weak, adding: It wasnapost nice to see. His legs trying to walk up the stairs would be shaking, like he couldnapost hold himself up. Asked what happened when Hughes arrived at her home to pick up Tustin, Ms Milhench added: He parked on my drive. Tom had himby the scruff, took him out. I remember Arthur falling on the floor. He just collapsed and fell into the car. The court heard Tustin ed to complete her hair appointment on June , arriving at around .am. During the visit, Ms Milhench said Tustin and Hughes were constantly swearing at Arthur like a game of tennis, with Tustin going on to claim that Arthur was being pressure-pointed. Ms Milhench said she had suggested Arthur should be sent to live with his grandmother, but was told that would be what he wants and would allow him to win. The court was also told that Ms Milhenchaposs partner, Tobias Jarman, snuck a drink of water to Arthur without Tustin and Hughes knowing. Mr Jarman, who said Arthur looked malnourished and had cracked lips, told the court: I tried to reassure him. I said, aposyou have not got to be scared of me in any wayapos. He look petried. It was not the normal glow you see in a kidaposs eyes of that age. It looked like there was fear ingrained inside of there. Hughes and Tustin deny murder. title: supermarkets pack fresh food aisles
story: Supermarkets pack fresh food aisles with HP sauce and Lynx in bid to hide empty shelvesA massive sunflower oil display replaced frozen items in the freezer aisle at one Tesco Extra in Cardf while staff at a Co-Op branch stuck HP and Salad cream in their refrigerated aisleOne Co-Op branch was rumbled after stacking Heinz Salad Cream and HP sauce in a refrigerator Image: twitter OnlyOneTByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Supermarkets are stacking empty shelves with strange items in response to Christmas shortages. Customers have been snapping the odd product choices in supermarkets like Tesco, Co-op and Asda across the country.It comes as Brits are warned of a light Christmas ahead after the UKaposs biggest container port reached capacity and was forced to turn ships away. Products are now being delayed and not making it into stores, according to reports. The shortages have been noticed by Brits up and down the country, who have been taking photographs of the rogue choices. One shared an image of fresh food crates at a Co-Op in Hertfordshire loaded with Quality Street, Celebrations and Dairy Milk instead of vegetables. Meanwhile, an Asda in Gloucester stretched out a display of Lynx deodorant to cover most of its toiletry aisle.  A Tesco Extra in Cardf was mocked after a massive sunflower oil display was spotted in the frozen food aisle. Staff at another Co-Op branch stuck rows of squeezey bottles of Heinz Salad Cream and HP sauce in refrigerators. The rogue items have been appearing in stores as shipping giant AP Moller-Maersk is erting vessels from their facility in Felixstowe, Suffolk. The Danish company warned the problem will continue into the new year. The issue has reportedly been caused by a lack of lorry drivers, a spike in imports and Covid restrictions at ports combining in a aposperfect stormapos.  Lars Mikael Jensen, head of the east-west network at Maersk, said containers are stacking up in Felixstowe because there are not enough drivers to aposget boxes outapos.Most imported toys come through the port, raising fears there will be shortages over Christmas, The Times reports. And today Tory Chancellor Rishi Sunak did little to reassure customers when discussing shortages - confessing that the government canapost fix every single problem.As fears grow of kids waking up on Christmas Day to empty stockings, the Chancellor said the Government were do absolutely everything we can to solve the British port issues.  Diverted ships are being unloaded at ports where, including Rotterdam, Antwerp and Bremerhaven, and are then transferred to smaller vessels to be transported to the UK. The process is reportedly causing delays of up to a week. Mr Jensen previously told : There is a shortage of truckers in the UK. Normally after four to five days the containers are out of the terminal and into a warehouse in Birmingham or wherever before coming back empty. “The trouble is that now we don’t have the same speed of flow of boxes moving in and out. With fewer truckers on average it takes longer to get boxes out of the terminal, so they are left standing. He also told The Times: We had to stop operations on a ship because there was nowhere to discharge the containers. Felixstowe is among the three worst affected ports in the world, Mr Jensen said. One shipping boss told The Times: I donapost want to sound like a Grinch but there are going to be gaps on shelves this Christmas. Mike Bowden, procurement manager at the shipping group Cory Brothers, added the port is so full of containers that new ones cannot be unloaded - and empty ones cannot be put back on ships. The Department of Transport told The Times that the issue was not aposunique to the UKapos, adding that ports around the world are battling container capacity and supply chain issues. title: teen develops tourettes like ticks
story: Mum says  teens at same college suffered Tourettes-like ticks from nowhereMadison Collins, , began suffering from head jerks and ticks, which mum Melanie says seemed to "come from nowhere" in January of this year - with the attacks getting so bad she has ended up in hospital unable to breatheMadison Collins began suffering from head jerks and ticks, which mum Melanie says seemed to come from nowhere Image: Kennedy News and MediaByNia Price:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA teenager reportedly developed Touretteaposs-like ticks at the same time as  other people in her college. Madison Collins began suffering from head jerks and ticks, which mum Melanie says seemed to come from nowhere in January of this year.Melanie, , described how one frightening attack in June left -year-old Madison, known as Madi, unable to breathe and needing hospital treatment. The worried mum said she now fears the ticks are being caught via social media after learning  other girls developed similar symptoms.The manager said Madi is now aposticking every dayapos to the point where sheaposs repeated phrases  times, punched herself and her hands have even locked into place for three hours. Melanie remains sceptical that her daughteraposs sudden condition is caused by social media specically as she questions why boys have been less affected, however she said she aposwouldnapost rule it outapos. She is now speaking out about Madiaposs situation and urging parents with similar experiences to come forward to find its cause. Melanie, of Clacton-on-Sea, Essex, said: [The college] said that they had  girls and one boy that have ticks at the moment. I was relieved. I know thataposs an awful thing to say but hearing that made me know that something has actually happened.  Something is happening to make this happen to girls andI can find a reason for it, I can deal with it better. If somethingaposs happening as a nation, we need to get to the bottom of it. We owe it to our daughters to find out why this is happening and what we can do to make sure it doesnapost happen to other girls her age. I just felt like I wanted to do something and rather than sitting there speculating, I want to find out for myself how big of a problem this is rather than being told aposthis is happeningapos. I want to get people together so we can do something about it. I think thereaposs strength in numbers and rather than this getting pushed under the carpet,I can find other people going through this, we can push this to the government level to get something done about it and get proper research to find what the cause is. Research led by Dr Kirsten Muller-Vahl at the Hannover University Medical School stated that a spike in patients displaying aposticksapos positively correlated to a rise in videos featuring Touretteaposs on sites such as TikTok, YouTube and Instagram.The study claimed the rise in ticks could be viewed as a aposstress reactionapos to societyaposs emphasis on iniduality and aposvaluing their alleged exceptionalityapos, which they say promotes aposattention-seeking behavioursapos. Worried Melanie has read the articles on the subject and also heard the condition linked to stress from the pandemic but she remains unsure what is causing it. However she refuses to rule anything out and called for more people to come forward so that more research can be done.  Melanie said: Online articles are saying that social media sites like TikTok is a probable cause. One of them is that people are going on there to highlight their ticks and thataposs starting off other kids to have it. On my LinkedIn posts there have been comments that have been said about that social media is being looked into as a possible cause, people have said aposmaybe social media is the reason whyapos, thereaposs been a couple of articles as well that have been linked on my LinkedIn post. My gut is telling me that itaposs external. Something has happened which is affecting girls. A lot of people are putting it down to [social media] or the stress of the pandemic but Iaposm not convinced of that because Madi will delete her social media every so often. Andshe feels like sheaposs becoming a bit consumed by social media she will delete it from time to time and will almost hit a reset and then go back to it. When I asked her about her stress levels during the pandemic she wasnapost particularly overly stressed. Iaposm not saying that it hasnapost played a part in it, Iaposm just not convinced she was stressed enough to bring on ticks. But then I donapost know, Iaposm not a medical doctor. I donapost think itaposs social media because I thinkit was social media,it was TikTok, like people are saying, I think boys would be affected. I wouldnapost rule it out. But I just thinkit was social media, it would affect boys as well, particularly as this condition is more prevalent in boys than it is in girls.  Melanie, who described her daughter as aposreliableapos, aposactiveapos and aposfunnyapos said she never had any of these symptoms as a child and from her understanding most children with Touretteaposs usually get recognised by the child is six-years-old. The devoted mum said sheaposs also been told by professionals that normally cases of Touretteaposs are more prevalent in boys. However, in the last  months thereaposs been a massive spike in referrals for girls between the ages of -. Melanie said: It was probably about eight months ago that she started these head ticks where she was jolting her head and they started getting progressively worse. Then she started having almost seizure-type ticks where her eyes would roll in the back of her head. We had to phone the ambulance, sheaposs been to hospital about it twice. They were so bad that she couldnapost breathe properly. It was almost like a seizure but when she was in hospital they confirmed it wasnapost because her vitals were quite normal, so it was just a tick spasm attack. It was frightening to watch. Sheaposs had a few of those. And then the vocal ticks about this time started kicking in as well. Madi says the ticks have had a dramatic effect on her daily le.  Her ticks include clicking noises, neck jerks, punching herself, vocal ticks in which she repeats a phrase repeatedly, sometimes for a whole day, scratching herself and even banging her head against the table. Madi said: When the ticks were small it didnapost really matter and to be honest I put it down to anxiety ticks for quite a long time and I just thought theyaposd go away. And when they got really bad it stopped everything. I used to read a lot and for a few weeks after my ticks got really bad I just couldnapost pick up a book, Iaposd just throw it. And there are still times I do throw my books. Just not as often now, you kind of learn how to deal with it. I wasnapost able to sit through my classes. I was told to leave a lot. I practically wasnapost able to do anything normal anymore. Everything became a lot harder. When I was working at the restaurant, I would have incidents where I would throw a glass on the floor. Then when I was trying to pick it up, I would just put it in my mouth and try to bite down unless someone took it out. There will be days where I can barely walk a few steps without falling over. When Iaposm trying to have a conversation with someone, my vocal ticks can get in the way and they can cause a lot of mishaps. For example, people think Iaposm calling them a b*tch or something. When Iaposm trying to do assessments or exams it can be really hard. I was trying to do an assessment in criminology and my hands locked so I was trying to do it with one hand and it didnapost unlock for three hours after, which is quite painful because itaposs quite a cramping one. Mum-of-three Melanie shared a post on LinkedIn and said that around - parents have contacted her, with around four or five of them saying their children have suddenly developed Touretteaposs.  She said that Madiaposs college have been aposabsolutely brilliantapos and theyaposve kept her included in all the decisions made surrounding her education. Melanie said: She hasnapost been diagnosed with Touretteaposs yet because she had to have symptoms for over a year to get diagnosed. Itaposs walking that fine line of not accepting it but at the same time accepting it because you donapost want her to feel uncomfortable by it. At the moment it looks like Touretteaposs, thataposs what itaposs presenting itself as. It was a lot to get my head around and to be honest itaposs only then when talking to the college that I was realising that other girls are going through this that I thought there must be a cause, andwe can find the reason weaposve got a better chance of finding treatment or a cure. Dr Muller-Vahl et alaposs study claimed teenagers were presenting ticks similar to a popular German YouTuber who demonstrated them in his videos, which have gone viral over the last two years. Suzanne Dobson of Touretteaposs Action, a UK-based charity that researches the condition and supports affected families, suggested in an interview earlier this year that social media may simply be encouraging teenage girls to be more open about their ticks. But she also speculated that gathering more aposlikesapos for demonstrating severe ticks, could be resulting in the girls no longer trying to stop the ticks. Hospitals in the UK claim to have seen an increase in ticks being reported in teenage girls since the pandemic. Great Ormond Street and Evelina Childrenaposs Hospitals each received between four and six referrals of ticks in teenage girls between -. However during the last three months of , this surged to each receiving three to four referrals per week. title: woman told cant pregnant after
story: Woman told she cant get pregnant after discovering she was born without a wombJaclyn Misch, from Michigan, USA has been diagnosed with Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser Type , a rare condition that occurs in females and mainly affects the reproductive systemJaclyn Misch was born without a womb Image: mediadrumworld   Jaclyn MiscByLiana Jacob:,  Oct | commentsA woman who was born without a womb is determined that she will become a mum. Jaclyn Misch, from Michigan, USA, was -years-old when she started to think she had a health issue as she hadnapost had her period yet. After several doctors appointments she was diagnosed with Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-HauserType , a rare condition that occurs in females and mainly affects the reproductive system. Essentially it means that she was born with no womb or cervix, and also has an incomplete vagina. A dilator was used to stretch her vaginal canal so that she could have penetrative sex, but she cannot carry her own child. In , the now -year-old who won the title of Miss Michigan USA , met Jonathan and then married him in .  The couple tried for a baby through IVF and gestational surrogacy, but after three failed embryo transfers they parted ways from their former carrier. They currently have a new gestational carrier that volunteered to potentially carry their baby. I was diagnosed with MRKH when I was sixteen my family physician was concerned I had never started my cycle but since I was lean and athletic, thought this might be the delay, Jaclyn said.  At sixteen years old, I really wanted to pretend that none of this was happening, so thataposs exactly what I did. Iaposd been trying so hard to fit in with my high school friends, but as fate would have it, my diagnosis had a dferent path planned for me. I was now one in , women around the world diagnosed with MRKH Syndrome. The fundamental biological traits that made me a woman, my self-identity and the plans for my future had shted.  I had to use dilators to have sex, I would never have a period and be like my girlfriends and I would never carry a child. I didnapost feel the same as other females and I frankly still donapost. Jaclyn said she kept quiet about the condition for years, not even telling members of her own family. Husband Jonathan helped the wine educator and marketer open up. He encouraged me to enter my first pageant and I won, she continued. I truly feel like I won as a way to use the  to spread awareness about MRKH syndrome. At the time of my diagnosis, there was no social media and the only thing my parents and I could find online about it were a few research articles. I felt confused, scared and angry. I ignored most of my emotion towards it and didnapost want to think about it.  It took me years to come to terms with the diagnoses and fully process. I had to learn to become comfortable in my own skin again for sixteen years of my le I had been conditioned by society and our culture to think I would grow up, get married and have a baby. Jaclyn had long hoped that she would one day become a mum.  I played with baby dolls and dreamt of having a baby bump, she continued. So when the diagnosis came, my self-identity shted and I had to start envisioning a le without the blessing of pregnancy. As far as sexual intercourse goes, I think itaposs important to preface this by saying everything is aposnormalapos down there on the outside. But girls with MRKH have a aposshallowapos vaginal canal, meaning in order to have sexual intercourse you need to self-dilate . Or have surgery to elongate the vaginal canal my doctor and I decided dilation was my best option, as itaposs also the first line of treatment recommended by The American College of Gynaecology.  I didnapost have much of an issue and things went quickly and smoothly. As happy as the couple are together, MRKH has had an affect on their relationship. Iaposve been with my husband Jonathan since  and I have to say that my diagnosis affects our relationship emotionally in our journey to parenthood, Jaclyn said. Seeing our friends get pregnant so fast and easily will always strike a small chord in my mind. Of course, Iaposm happy for them but always wishing to have that ability myself. After our three failed embryo transfers and parting ways with our previous gestational carrier I was a mess. Asking myself what my le purpose is, will we ever have a child of our own  I was completely deflated, and it hit me much harder than Jonathan. Instead of the path to parenthood being joyful and happy ours is stressful, emotional, and draining both mentally and financially. Our journey to parenthood is by far the most challenging. For the longest time, Iaposve seen PGS aposchromosomally normalapos embryos taking on the first time. Iaposve had friends with MRKHget pregnant on their first transfer with their high-quality embryos so naturally, I thought we would too as our embryos were perfectly normal. But that wasnapost the case three times in a row. The waiting period is also extremely dficult. Between transfers, waiting for the two-week pregnancy blood test building up excitement only to be completely deflated with the negative results. Currently, we have a new gestational carrier and are beyond grateful that she and her husband have volunteered to help us start a family. We are in the process of having her screened by our IVF doctor. Jaclyn hopes that others will gain strength from her story. She said: You are never alone so many women have been diagnosed with MRKH from around the world there is an entire network of MRKH sisters waiting for you with encouragement, understanding and support through every phase of MRKH. story: Mystery beast with no eyes, ears or mouth stuns er in depths of the Red SeaLukas Ostertag, from Heidelberg, Germany, was one of those who encountered the freaky sea beast, which he described as being a “long square rubber pipe-like thing”, while ing.Lukas and his fellow ers eventually determined the object was the leftover arms of the jellyfish, probably after being devoured by a sea turtle Image: Credit: Pen News Lukas OstertagByAlice Peacock:,  Oct | commentsA bizarre tube-shaped creature with no eyes, ears or a mouth stunned ers in the depths of the Red Sea. Lukas Ostertag was one of the underwater group who encountered the freaky sea beast while ing in the Sataya Reef, off the Egyptian coast. The -year-old described the creature’s appearance as being a “long square rubber pipe-like thing” with a pointy end. “It looked like nothing Iaposve seen before,” he said. It definitely was super strange as it seemed to move on its own and nobody knew what it was. Lukas said it reminded him of the Yrr - a fictional deep-sea species hellbent on destroying mankind, dreamed up by Frank Sch tzing for his novel, The Swarm.  He and his fellow ers thought it might be a kind of polyp - a soft-bodied organism related to sea anemones and jellyfish. Others guessed it to be a worm or a kind of plant, Lukas said, while one other person thought it might be a jellyfish. Looking for answers, Lukas, from Heidelberg, Germany, shared his photos with an online group dedicated to identying marine animals. However, the members seemed to share his confusion. One person wrote: Wow this thing is a puzzler. I could see it being a siphonophore, soft coral, pyrosome, maybe nemertean, or jellyfish arm. Iaposm stumped.  Another commented: Looks like a nemertean - ribbon worm, but the jellyfish part is possible as well. In the end, Lukas got an answer when footage emerged from another group that had been ing the same reef. In the end we figured out it was from a jellyfish as another e group the same day made a video,” he said. The thing we saw was the leftover arms of the jellyfish, probably after being devoured by a sea turtle. I guess in the end the arms were still moving a bit because the jellyfish was not eaten long ago.  The specic species is thought to be the Thysanostoma lorerum. Lukas said it had been “fun” figuring out what the creature was after being “so clueless” upon the initial sighting. “That we found out it was a jellyfish was pure luck,” he said. title: thought for the week september 24 2021
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowI had the wonderful privilege the other week of holding a new grandson for the first time.Isn#t it amazing how a new-born infant can grab hold of your heart  I was filled with so much love and pride and I prayed that his le would be blessed.It so happened that the Gospel reading set for the Sunday after I met my grandson was, in part at least, about a little child.​Mark tells us Jesus was walking ahead of his disciples on the way to Capernaum. When they got there Jesus asked them: #What were you arguing about along the way #They couldn#t answer, for they had been arguing about which of them was the greatest. They were silent, because they#d been caught out.Then Jesus took a little child in his arms and said to them: #Whoever welcomes one such child in my name welcomes me, and whoever welcomes me, welcomes not me but the one who sent me.#Greatness, Jesus was saying to them, is found in welcoming and receiving into our arms someone vulnerable, powerless and dependent, regardless of age.Greatness is found not in what we have accomplished but in what we have done and given to #the least of these#, the hungry, thirsty, naked, sick, and imprisoned: the symbolic children in each of our lives.Greatness never makes itself superior over another. It is not about me, my job, my reputation, my status. Our greatness is revealed in our service and care of others.Max is doing well, by the way, and I can hardly wait to see him again.God bless you and yours, from biggest to littlest, today and always.

title: letters to the editor september 24 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Sir,Dr Jeremy Phillips and Dr Rebecca Helliwell wish to thank the community and patients of Mid Argyll Medical Practice for their kindness and good wishes marking their leaving the practice earlier this month.It has been a real privilege and honour to have been so closely and intimately involved with the lives of so many people and families over the last  and  years respectively.We will always be grateful for this and the opportunity to work with a excellent loyal and dedicated group of staff in the practice, hospital and in the wider NHS team.We will both continue to live locally and continue to work in the NHS in Argyll.Dr Jeremy Phillips and Dr Rebecca HelliwellSir,Looking into the future of marine planning, West Coast Regional Inshore Fisheries Grouphas formed an aquaculture sub-group to foster better communications and understanding between commercial fishing and aquaculture.Both are integral to coastal communities which are economically dependent on them.After the initial meeting it was agreed that there were synergies to be had working with other areas around Scotland, and the group was expanded to become simply the RIFG Aquaculture Working Group.The driving force comes from the proposed huge future expansion of aquaculture, the fact that fishers were not considered, historically, as mandatory consultees and also the promise of a review by Scottish Government of the aquaculture licencing process.It was felt that now was a good time for inshore fishers, through the RIFG, to consider, collate and communicate their views to any, and all, of the regulatory bodies involved in the said licencing process.The working group is particularly concerned with the aquaculture planning process # especially when it comes to the impact of proposed sites on traditional fishing grounds # poor site maintenance and monitoring which can lead to instances of vessel entanglement and also the environmental impact of the sites on both commercial and non-commercial species.The group believes that while the sector has made many advances over the past decade, increased transparency and oversight are needed to ensure the aquaculture sector can better co-exist with the fishing industry.The initial aim of the group would be to ensure that there is a proper analysis of localised fishing and follow up with clear and sensible communication between the two sectors to ensure that with expansion does not come conflict.It is a timeous idea, which will hopefully reassure fishermen that they will not simply be displaced by fish farming but will be respected for their own produce.The group will cement a policy to assist the fishing industry deal realistically with the fish farming industry and the Scottish Salmon Producers Organisation.Simon Macdonald, chair RIFG Aquaculture Work GroupSir,NFU Scotland is calling on the UK Government to address the nation’s growing labour crisis, which is undermining all parts of the food and drink supply chain, leading to signicant losses on some Scottish farms and resulting in a growing number of empty shop shelves.Last week#s #BackBritishFarmingDay on September  came as a UK Government announcement of a free trade #agreement in principle# between the UK and New Zealand is believed to be imminent.Having agreed in June to provide unfettered access in the future to Australia, the cumulative impact of another deal with a major exporting nation has huge signicance for Scottish farmers and crofters.With so much to celebrate about the quality and standards of our food and drink, #BackBritishFarmingDay was a fantastic opportunity to thank the nation for their incredible support throughout Brexit and Covid-.NFU Scotland, both independently and in conjunction with the Scottish food and drink industry, has written several times to UK Government calling for measures that address the shortfall in both seasonal and permanent staff.Should it fail to do so, I have absolutely no doubt that the situation will deteriorate further.It is galling to hear that the UK Government is on the verge of signing up to another free trade deal that will permit a growing level of imports while delivering very little to our food and drink sector in .The blunt fact is that neither deal has been afforded any kind of proper parliamentary scrutiny as the government’s promised Statutory Trade and Agriculture Commission has yet to be established.Safeguards against market disruption are also promised, but the cumulative impact of these deals will be profound for UK farming.If handled badly, these may make it impossible for some of our family farming businesses to continue to compete with high levels of low-cost imports produced to standards that would not be allowed here.Martin Kennedy, president, NFU ScotlandSir,National audits of diabetic services have shown that only around  per cent of people with type one or two diabetes have nine key annual checks to help prevent long-term diabetic complications.The pandemic has made this situation dficult because many routine checks and face-to-face appointments have not been available.The InDependent Diabetes Trusthas published a free new booklet which explains the nine key tests.It helps people look after their health by ensuring that they know what checks they need from health professionals.Get your copy of Diabetes care # your  key checks by contacting IDDT on  , emailing enquiries@iddtinternational.org or writing to IDDT, PO Box , Northampton NN XS.Jenny Hirst, InDependent Diabetes Trust

title: sru-coaching-boost-womens-rugby-borders
story: KELSO and Biggar are two of  Scottish rugby clubs selected to take part in a new SRU lsquoCoach Support Programmersquo in partnership with SP Energy Networks to support girlsrsquo rugby coaching groups across the country.The programme aims to strengthen coaching skills and support young female players towards performance improvements and will run initially between October and December .The Bordersrsquo sides will work with an appointed Coach Development Officer from Scottish Rugby, who will provide club coaches with bespoke support including -to- meetings, development plans, match and training observations and reviews.The  coaching groups selected for the programme are: Angus Girls, Kelpies Rugby, Garioch RFC, Orkney RFC, Edinburgh Harlequins, Kelso RFC, Biggar RFC, Whitecraigs RFC, Annan RFC and Greenock Wanderers.The programme kicked off on Monday  October with an online session for clubs to meet their Coach Development Officer and learn more about the programme, its details and objectives.Neil Graham, Head of Training  Education at Scottish Rugby said: ldquoWe are delighted to have SP Energy Networks supporting the delivery of the programme. Coaches are a crucial component in nurturing environments which allow players to develop and hone their skills.ldquoBy engaging in the programme our  selected coaching groups can expect to gain a deeper understanding of their coaching practice, identy areas of strength and development, and a greater breadth of knowledge to help them deal with day-to-day coaching situations.ldquoItrsquos our hope that the programme will create longer-term benefits for girls in the game, to keep them engaged with the sport and support their inidual overall development as they progress towards senior rugby.Frank Mitchell, CEO of SP Energy Networks said: ldquoSP Energy Networks is passionate about inspiring and supporting women and girls both on the rugby pitch, and in the workplace. Our partnership with the Scotland womenrsquos team is evidence of that commitment. Our aim has always been to support and drive forward grassroots rugby, placing ourselves closer to the communities we serve, whilst also striving to raise awareness of engineering as a career choice ndash especially for women and girls.ldquoTogether we have developed this new programme to break barriers and empower girlsrsquo rugby across Scotland. It is a deepening of our support of womenrsquos rugby in Scotland, to ensure that potential international stars of the future are working with best-in-class coaches.ldquoThe work these coaches have already done, and will continue to do, is instrumental in inspiring the next generation and we are proud to support them through this and beyond.

story: THE SCOTTISH SPCA is appealing for people with rural properties to come forward as potential new homes for members of a feral cat colony.Scotlandrsquos animal welfare charity is working with Cats Protection to trap and neuter around  cats of ious ages ahead of the colony being dispersed.Scottish SPCA inspector, Gillian Dick, said, ldquoNormally we would simply neuter feral cats andthem to their territory.ldquoHowever, this colony is very large and has become dependent on an elderly member of the public for food. They are struggling to care for the cats and there are concerns what will happen to the animals in the futurethe situation is left unchecked.ldquoWe want to disperse the colony and relocate the cats as pairs or single animals to rural properties throughout Scotland.ldquoThey will need to have a secure, indoor space where the felines can settle in initially until they are used to their new home.ldquoWe must stress that these animals are feral and will not be suitable as pets in a normal household. However, they are likely to be excellent mousers and would thrive as working animals in a rural or farm setting.ldquoIf you think you could provide a home for some of these cats please call our animal helpline on   .A Cats Protection spokesman said: ldquoWe are pleased to be working closely with the Scottish SPCA to find a solution to this feral situation.ldquoThis is a good example of what we can do working together for animal welfare, and we look forward to finding more suitable homes for these cats.

title: borders-railway-extension-project-truly-transform-region
story: THE extension of the Borders Railway has been described as the ldquobest solution to tackle the regionrsquos transport connectivity issues.Extending the line through to Carlisle has been a hot central Scottish Borders has brought immense and wide-ranging benefits that we continue to try to maximise.ldquoScottish Borders Council has made a case for the extension of the line to Hawick and on to Carlisle for some time, and together with the other Borderlands local authority partners we are reaffirming and strengthening that case in the prospectus.The partnership is made up of SBC Dumfries and Galloway Council Carlisle City Council Cumbria County Council and Northumberland County Council.The prospectus outlines challenges in the region, such as residents struggling to access key services and car dependency.:Aldi: Supermarket chain has plans to open new Borders locationOutward migration is another problem that the prospectus links with the transport connectivity issues ndash with Hawickrsquos population falling by  per cent from  to the s.However, the document does not provide a view on where stations should be located on the route, which will be a matter for the feasibility study.The extension of the Borders Railway is described in the prospectus as the ldquomissing link to reconnect the region.John Lamont, Conservative MP for Berwickshire, Roxburgh  Selkirk, described the document as ldquoimpressive and informative.ldquoThis project has the potential to truly transform towns and villages along the line ndash opening up educational and work opportunities, as well as making our area a more desirable place to live, he said.:Concerns raised over new plans for Lidl to be part of Borders Gateway projectldquoThese proposals have been under consideration for Railway truly live up to its name.Work to assess the challenges and benefits of the extension is part of the Borderlands Inclusive Growth Deal ndash which was signed on March  by both UK and Scottish governments, and the five Borderlands partners.The deal will bring in up to poundmillion of fresh investment to the Borderlands area.

story: A COMMUNITY run shop in Peeblesshire celebrated its official launch at the weekend.The Knot, in West Linton, has been up and running for a number of weeks.But it was officially opened on Saturdayat a special ceremony.The shop, which was formerly the Red Cross, offers books, secondhand clothes and homewares and has an additional gallery space for local artists to display and sell their work.:Aldi: Supermarket chain has plans to open new Peeblesshire locationAt the ceremony, Ian Reid, one of the members of the committee behind the shop, said: "Were so chuffed that so many people are here today."From am members of the community gathered at the Village Centre for homemade cakes before a procession from Raemartine Square to the shop on Main Street.A cake, which had been made by John Adam of Innerleithen, was decorated with a knot design by committee member Anne Suckling.And visitors to the village Jill and John Smart, who were on holiday in West Linton from Macclesfield were chosen to cut the cake.:Coronavirus: No new deaths in Borders for first time since August, figures showJoining the parade through the village was piper Glyn Morris who performed an original composition, Cut the Ribbon, created by resident Ben Gibbs.Councillor Heather Anderson, who represents Tweeddale West, shared on social media after the event: "It was just great to see the Knot officially opened [yesterday] with the splendid assistance of magnicent piper, Glyn Morris, who came all they way to West Linton to pipe us in."Many thanks to everyone who turned out in the rain and produced all those wonderful cakes in the Visitor Centre beforehand."It was a real pleasure to join you for the celebration.":Child, , hurt after being caught up in brawl near Borders primary schoolAnd untying the knot on the door to the shop were two of the young volunteers working with The Knot, Galina MacNeacail and Charlotte Wakelin-Grant.

title: knights-cgi-work-community-based-initiatives
story: AFTER A long period of no competitive rugby, Southern Knights are thrilled to have reached the  final of the FOSROC Super Rugby League and are particularly grateful to main sponsor global IT and business consulting services company CGI for their support over the past two years.Rob Chrystie, Head coach at the Southern Knights, said: ldquoThe Southern Knights management and players have really enjoyed theirto rugby since the end of July.CGI, our headline sponsor have shown unwavering support to the Southern Knights throughout extremely challenging times. We are exceptionally grateful for their continued support and determined to repay that commitment on the pitch whist working closely with them in the wider Borders community.ldquoDuring lockdown we were able to continue to offer rugby activities for the younger children, and during April we were able to support a new Try It Out campaign aimed at children that wouldnrsquot typically have access to rugby or sporting activities because of social or economic barriers. We feel very strongly that the ability to pay shouldnrsquot prevent access to sport.ldquoParents and carers were offered the option to pay what they could, or in some cases nothing at all. Over  boys and girls joined in the fun sessions at the Melrose pitches, and the majority registered to stay on until the end of the summer season. The lting of restrictions has allowed the Southern Knights to launch their buddy scheme aligning some of their semi-professional players to the younger players to help encourage and develop their skills and to inspire children to play to the best of their ability.ldquoThis inclusive ethos is shared by CGI and the award winning Inspire Learning Programme developed in partnership with Scottish Borders Council for pupils from primary four to sixth year in high school throughout the area.ldquoThis uses iPads and an array of other tools to support learning and aims to benefit all children and teachers by raising attainment, support equity and inclusion, and to work towards preparing young people for a digital future. We are keen to continue to support these initiatives in conjunction with CGI over the coming months and years.Dominic Taddei, Chair of Southern Knights Super Board said: ldquoWe are delighted to continue to work a further term with our headline sponsor CGI. Their support through very dficult times has been phenomenal and we look forward to working with them as we get ready to approach the finals day, and to now have the ability to offer a wider audience for FOSROC Super with the fantastic news that was released by Scottish Rugby on rd June  that every Super Sunday fixture has been televised live on free-to-air television by new broadcast partner, FreeSports. The FOSROC Super finals weekend will take place on the weekend of    October, and we look forward to showcasing CGI as our headline sponsor at the finals event.The continuing partnership between CGI and the Southern Knights is not only a relationship supporting sport in the Scottish Borders but also Southern Knights players and coaches are working closely with CGI on community-based initiatives in Borders schools, delivering motivational and inspirational videos for the pupils. CGI employees will also benefit from the relationship with the option to join in fitness sessions at the Greenyards and receiving motivational and leadership messages from the coaches.

title: around-43-000-people-given-wrong-pcr-covid-test-results
story: An estimated , people may have been given wrong negative PCR Covid test results, the UK Health Security Agencyhas said.NHS Test and Trace has suspended testing operations provided by Immensa Health Clinic Ltd at its laboratory in Wolverhampton, following an investigation into reports of people receiving negative PCR test results after they have previously tested positive on a lateral flow.A negative PCR means people will not have needed to isolate and could potentially have spread the infection to many other people.The errors relate to test results given to people between September  and October , mainly in the South West of England, but with some cases in the South East and Wales.There are no technical issues with test kits themselves and people should continue to test as normal, UKHSA said.It said a full investigation is being carried out into why and how incorrect results were given.Dr Jenny Harries, the chief executive of UKHSA, told the BBC it was likely only a few thousand of the , affected were still infectious.She added that it was ldquonot clear yet what went wrong in the private laboratory, adding that it was ldquoaccredited to all of the appropriate standards.vw,vw,px, px"NHS Test and Trace estimates that around , samples have been processed through the lab, but new samples are now being redirected to other labs.Test and Trace is contacting people who could still be infectious to advise them to take another test, while close contacts who are symptomatic will also be advised to take a test, as is already recommended.PCR tests can detect Covid- several weeks after infection.If a person has a positive lateral flow result, they are told to have a follow-up PCR to confirm the finding.Dr Will Welfare, public health incident director at UKHSA, said: ldquoWe have recently seen a rising number of positive LFDresults subsequently testing negative on PCR.ldquoAs a result of our investigation, we are working with NHS Test and Trace and the company to determine the laboratory technical issues which have led to inaccurate PCR results being issued to people.ldquoWe have immediately suspended testing at this laboratory while we continue the investigation.ldquoThere is no evidence of any faults with LFD or PCR test kits themselves and the public should remain confident in using them and in other laboratory services currently provided.ldquoIf you get a positive LFD test, itrsquos important to make sure that you then get a follow-up PCR test to confirm you have Covid-.ldquoIf you have symptoms of Covid-, self-isolate and take a PCR test.The Government awarded Immensa a pound million contract in October  to urgently ldquodevelop volume for PCR testing for Covid in line with test and trace requirements, the contract shows.The contract did not go to tender under rules allowing urgent responses to the pandemic.A further pound million was awarded to Immensa by the Government in a contract last September.Immensa was incorporated as a company in the UK in May .vw,vw,px, px"According to the Immensa website, the firm was new to Covid testing. It said: ldquoIn , we adapted and evolved into Covid- testing, taking advantage of our laboratory network, scientic expertise, and digital systems to deliver world-leading Covid- testing solutions.Andrea Riposati, chief executive of Immensa, said: ldquoWe are fully collaborating with UKHSA on this matter.ldquoQuality is paramount for us. We have proudly analysed more than . million samples for NHS Test and Trace, working closely with the great teams at the Department for Health and UKHSA.ldquoWe do not wish this matter or anything  to tarnish the amazing work done by the UK in this pandemic.Among the testing sites affected are Newbury Showground in Berkshire.A man from nearby Swindon said his confidence in the accuracy of his recent Covid test result has been impacted by the issue at the Immensa laboratory.Tim Barton, , told the PA news agency he and his family received positive lateral flow tests after falling ill with coronavirus symptoms earlier this month but their PCR tests came back negative.The client relationship director said: ldquoMy son, daughter and myself all had positivendash we then had PCR tests done at the test site in Swindon all of which came back negative.ldquoThis will undoubtedly impact peoplersquos confidence in the accuracy of these types of testshellip they could have cost lives.Meanwhile, in Wales, around , people may have been affected from testing sites in the Gwent and Cwm Taf Morgannwg areas.Immensa is part of Dante labs, whose chief executive is Mr Riposati.The Competition and Markets Authorityannounced in September it was investigating Dante Labs over concerns it may be treating customers unfairly.This included by not delivering PCR tests and or results on time or at all, failing to respond to complaints or provide proper customer service, refusing or delaying refunds when requested and using terms and conditions which may unfairly limit consumersrsquo rights.The CSA said Dante was ldquoa popular provider of PCR travel tests in the UK this summer..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Around , people  ugiven wrong PCR Covid test results u

title: childhood-friend-manchester-bomber-ordered-attend-public-inquiry
story: A childhood friend of the Manchester Arena bomb plotters will be forced to answer questions at the public inquiry into the atrocity next week or face arrest, a judge ruled on Friday.Ahmed Taghdi, , helped buy the brothers a car which was later used to store components of the bomb which Salman Abedi later assembled and detonated on May   at the end of an Ariana Grande concert, murdering  bystanders and injuring hundreds more.And Mr Taghdi, along with Salman Abedi, had visited in jail convicted terrorist Abdalraouf Abdallah, who terror experts believe ldquogroomed Salman into a radicalised Islamist extremist.vw,vw,px, px"Sir John Saunders, chairman of the Manchester Arena Inquiry Families of victims, along with chairman of the inquiry, Sir John Saunders, want Mr Taghdi to give evidence at the public hearings next week.Sir John has ordered Mr Taghdi to attend on Thursday but, through his lawyers, he has so far refused, even though he has the legal right to refuse to answer any questions that could incriminate himself.On Friday the matter went before Mr Justice Jacobs, sitting at the High Court in Manchester, with an application for a court order compelling Mr Taghdi to attend next Thursday andhe does not, to be arrested for breaking the order and brought to the inquiry hearing.Richard Wright QC, representing Mr Taghdi, opposed the application, telling the hearing his client was a vulnerable witness, suffering a ldquomild to moderate depressive illness.And he said Mr Taghdi had fears over his own and his familyrsquos securityhe appears as a witness and that having been questioned by police after the bombing and given a witness statement for the trial of Hashem Abedi, Salmanrsquos co-conspirator younger brother, his evidence would have nothing to add.However, Paul Greaney QC, counsel to the inquiry, said the criminal case was concerned with prosecuting Hashem Abedi, but the inquiryrsquos scope was wider and Mr Taghdi would be a key witness for Sir John Saunders.Mr Greaney said: ldquoHe has evidence of critical importance to give to the inquiry. He was a childhood friend of Salman Abedi and he is therefore singularly well placed to describe Abedirsquos journey towards radicalisation.He told the court the inquiry was also ldquovery interested in what was discussed when Mr Taghdi and Salman Abedi visited Abdallah in prison.And he said he was a witness of ldquoconsiderable signicance adding that Mr Taghdi was seen to visit the area where the Nissan Micra car was kept in the five weeks Salman Abedi was in Libya before ing to collect the bomb components from the car and carry out the attack.Mr Greaney said Mr Taghdi had been given ldquoevery chance to co-operate with the inquiry but failed to do so.Mr Taghdi, from Manchester, was arrested and questioned after the bombing but never charged with any offence and denies involvement or knowledge of the bomb plot by Salman and his brother Hashem Abedi.Mr Justice Jacobs granted the application for the order, backed by an arrest warrant should he not attend.He added: ldquoIt is beyond sensible argument that the respondenthas relevant evidence he can give to the inquiry.ldquoIt is justied in the circumstances of the present case so we will make the order which has been requested.Ismail Abedi, the bomb plottersrsquo older brother, and Abdalraouf Abdallah, are both due to give evidence next week, having initially declined to do so. Lawyers for Abdallah told the inquiry on Thursday he will not answer any questionshe is forced to attend.It is not yet knownany of them will attend the inquiry, which reconvenes on Monday..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Childhood friend of Manchester bomber ordered to attend public inquiry

title: patel-plans-visa-penalties-countries-not-cooperate-deportations
story: Priti Patel will be granted new powers to impose visa penalties on countries that do not cooperate on deportations, under new reforms in the Nationality and Borders Bill announced on Friday.The Home Secretary will be able to suspend visas entirely, impose a pound surcharge on applications to come to the UK or increase visa processing times.The powers will affect the whole visa service, including study, work, visitor and settlement visas.The aim is to encourage other countries to cooperate with the UK Government when it comes to deportations and removals.Ms Patel said: ldquoThe UK has a proud history of being open to the world but we rightly expect our international partners to work with us to remove those who have no right to be in the UK, such as dangerous foreign national offenders.ldquoIt is unfair on UK citizens and taxpayers that pressure is put on our public services by foreign nationals with no legal right#to be#here.ldquoThrough my New Plan for Immigration, and this landmark legislation, I will continue to take the dficult action needed to fix our broken asylum system and deliver on what the British people want ndash full control of our borders.Foreign criminals will also be able to be removed sooner.Under changes to the Early Removal Scheme, foreign national criminals will be eligible for removal up to  months before the end of their custodial sentence, as opposed to nine months. This is assuming theyrsquove served over half a custodial sentence.Minister for justice and tackling illegal migration, Tom#Pursglove, said the the New Plan for Immigration provides the only long-term solution to fix our ldquobroken asylum system.He added: ldquoWe are taking another step forward in delivering on this commitment as our Nationality and Borders Bill continues its passage through Parliament. We are ensuring our system is fair for those who play by the rules, but firm on foreign criminals and those in our country illegally.ldquoWe have brought forward the most signicant reforms to the immigration and asylum system in decades. This is what the British people have consistently demanded. Strengthening the Bill through these amendments will ensure that we continue to deliver for them.The US also requests that foreign governments take appropriate steps when it comes to deportations and removals. Any lack of cooperation from the nation of origin would in many cases result in visa sanctions, which can y in severity.At the beginning of the month, the EU temporarily suspended the application of certain provisions in the visa code to nationals from The Gambia.The decision was taken due to the countryrsquos lack of cooperation on readmission of third-country nationals illegally staying in the EU.Some of the other amendments tabled by the Government include expanding the types of claims that can be dealt with in an accelerated appeal from detention, so that more cases can be resolved while the person is in detention rather than them being released into the community.#This includes foreign national offenders.Over the coming week, the Government is also expected to introducea robust approach to age assessment to better identy asylum-seeking children and stop adults accessing childrenrsquos services and legislation to establish an Electronic Travel AuthorisationScheme.Once introduced, carriers will have to check that all passengershave a digital authorisation or some other form of permission before they can travel to the UK..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Patel plans visa penalties for countries that do not cooperate on deportations

title: scottish-parliament-recess-happens-mean-scotland
story: The Scottish Parliament is on recess from October  - , meaning chamber meetings and ministerial statments will not take place this week.Parliament recesses are breaks from normal order and usually take place several times a year in line with school and bank holidays.What do these recesses mean for politicsin Scotland  Heres everything you need to know...What areParliament recesses Parliament recesses arebreaks in the normal schedule when there are no meetings in the Chamber and no committee meetings.The Ocotberrecess is often seen as an "October holiday" for MSPs, althoughit is unlikely they will take the whole recess to recuperate.Do MSPs continue working during Parliament recess The recess allows MSPs to spend an extended period of time in their own constituencyand therefore with their constituents.MSPs are likely to take advantage of this time to maintain or increase rapport with their constituents by attending local events and generally keeping a fairly high profile.Recesses give MSPs time to make the visits that they might in normal times be too busy to carry out.Do First Ministers Questions continue during recess No, First Ministers Questions will not continue during recess.However, Parliament can be recalled over the course ofrecessrequired.Can Parliament berecalled at any time Parliament can be recalled from recess on request of the Government.For example, Parliament was recalled during recess in April following the death of Prince Philipto allow politicians in Scotlandto pay tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh.Can I still contact my MSP during Parliamentary recess Yes, you can still get in contact with your MSP during recesses and they may table questions to ask when Parliament s.When does the UK Parliament take nextrecess The UK Parliament will takerecess from November -.

title: christmas-shortages-2021-homemade-christmas-gift-ideas
story: With warnings of Christmas shortages due to supply chain issues and delivery delays, you might be thinking about giving homemade gts this year.Covid- and Brexitare among contributing factors, while an escalating dispute over fishing rights has led French fishing representatives to threaten a blockade at Calais to stop exports to the UK.Current issues have been put down to a "transition period" by Boris Johnsons administration, which they say will not cause "much risk" at Christmas.However, asindustry experts deemChristmas shortages "a certainty", making your own presents could help you to avoid potential delays or disappointment.Not only that, but family and friends are sure to appreciate the time andeffort that goes into creating ahand crafted gt.Here are some ideas for homemade presents this Christmas.... Homemade jam and chutneyThe festive period is a time for eating, so what better than cooking up a big batch of homemade jam or chutney for your loved ones.Start saving your jars now and by Christmas you will have plenty to fill.Hundreds of recipescan be found online andyou are cooking in large quantities, it wont necessarily be that expensive!Another positive is the long shelf le of such products, meaning people can enjoy them well into .. Christmas decorationsChristmas tree decorationsare an underrated gt - with people using the same items year after year, and even generation after generation, this could be your opportunity to leave your stamp on celebrations for decades to come.There are plenty of ideas online, but why not buy some cheap, clear plastic or glass bobbles which you can decorate with permanent markers, tippex pens or paint, before tying with ribbon.Baked salt dough can work just as well, while simple origami folding techniques can be used to transform a piece of paper into something special.. Photo albumsA photo album filled with memories could be the best present someone ever receives.It may be slightly time consuming, but a collection of photos reminding your loved ones of a special time in their le is a timeless classic which will never get old.Photo albums can be cheaply purchasedonline or in store - charity shops are a good place to start - and companieslike Free Printsmean you can order photographs for free from your phone.. Knitted socksIf you are a keen knitter, homemade socks are guaranteed to please as well as keep people warm through the cold winter months.. Sloe ginSloe gin is synonymous with aChristmas tipple, and as it turns out its pretty easy to make yourself, with some recipes only requiring three ingredients.Again, start saving bottles and by December you will be ready to decant.. Christmas bakingYou cant go wrong with some Christmas baking, whether it be mince pies, yule logs or mini Christmas puddings.Pop it in a box and tie with ribbon and you have yourself the perfect gt which will go down a treat while people wait for Christmas dinner.. VouchersIf you dont want to give physical gts, you could make a voucher for an experience to take your loved one out for coffee or dinner once the festive season is over.Its something to look forward to once Christmas is over, and gives you a chance to catch up on each others lives after the busy end-of-year period.

title: stirling-city-culture-scottish-city-makes-longlist---means
story: Stirling has been longlisted for the City of Culture , along with sevenother cities around the UK.It was one of three Scottish areas to apply, but the only one to make this years longlist in the biggest competition yet.The eight remaining citiesArmagh City,Bradford, County Durham,Cornwall, Derby, Southampton,Wrexham County Borough and Stirling will receive pound, ahead of the next stageof the competition.This money should be used to support each citys application, where they must show they can put "at the heart of their plans to recover from the impact of the pandemic".Heres everything you need to know aboutthe City of Culture competition and Stirlings chances...What is a City of Culture Every four years since , a city from somewhere in the UK has been selected as the city of culture.The idea was catalysed by Liverpools successas the European Capital of Culture in , with the first UK city of culture awarded to Derry Londonderry in .Kingston upon Hull won in  while Coventry
